title: 105_s2207
content: The "Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998" aims to empower the Attorney General to prevent mergers that could harm competition in the telecommunications industry. It amends the Clayton Act to address restraints of trade in telecommunications. The "Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998" defines a large local telephone company as one serving more than 5% of telephone access lines in the US. It prohibits mergers or acquisitions of such companies unless approved by the Attorney General and FCC to promote competition in telecommunications. The Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998 prohibits mergers or acquisitions of large local telephone companies unless approved by the Attorney General and FCC to promote competition in telecommunications. The FCC must ensure that the companies have fully implemented the requirements of the Communications Act of 1934. The Attorney General must report findings to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees within 10 days. The Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998 requires large local telephone companies to seek approval from the Attorney General and FCC for mergers or acquisitions to promote competition in the telecommunications industry. The Attorney General must report findings to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees within 10 days, including an analysis of the impact on competition. Companies must file applications with both the Attorney General and FCC simultaneously for review. The Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998 mandates that large local telephone companies seeking to merge must file applications with the Attorney General and FCC simultaneously. The Attorney General and FCC must issue a decision within the specified time frame, and the district courts have jurisdiction to prevent mergers inconsistent with competition findings. The Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998 requires large local telephone companies to file merger applications with the Attorney General and FCC simultaneously. The Attorney General or FCC can take legal action in district court if a proposed merger does not meet competition conditions. SEC. 4 of the Act preserves existing authorities related to antitrust laws and FCC regulations for mergers involving large incumbent local exchange carriers. SEC. 5 specifies that the Act applies to mergers or acquisitions of controlling interests in large local telephone companies occurring after the Act's enactment.
